Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Svalbard REU: Holocene and Modern Climate Change in the Norwegian High Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration: Since 2003, the PIs have been administering an REU site in the Svalbard archipelago for motivated geoscience undergraduate students, directly involving them in important climate change research and exposing them to the challenges and rewards of conducting high latitude research. Funds are provided to continue the Svalbard REU program for another year, based on the success of the program. Student research focuses on the climatic and surficial processes that operate in rapidly changing glacial, lacustrine, and fjord systems that may, in turn, archive the signature of anthropogenic changes in the high Arctic. Students define their research questions and design specific testable hypotheses throughout the program, complete their research projects at their home institutions during the following academic year and present their results at a professional conference. Most alumni of the program have gone into graduate programs better prepared for fundamental research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Svalbard REU was specifically designed to train the next generation of scientists, with emphasis on climate change in a rapidly changing arctic environment. Undergraduate students gained experience in field and laboratory techniques and developed independent and collaborative projects during a 4 week field program in Svalbard, Norwegian arctic.  The senior personnel in our project have vast research experience in the arctic marine environment and are dedicated teachers. Through constant contact with the students throughout their summer experience, training and development activities are hands-on and personalized.

 

The most recent field season (2014) was completed in Kongsfjord (79oN) where contemporary studies of tidewater glacier margins provide an unparalleled opportunity for introducing motivated undergraduate students to the challenges and rewards of polar geoscientific field research. Rates of rapid change in this high-latitude Arctic environment emphasize the complexity of the Earth System at the interface of the ice, ocean, and atmosphere. The rigors of studying an actively calving glacier also built on their outdoor skills, especially when it is necessary to improvise and become resourceful due to instrumentation failures or weather-related delays. Self-confidence and problem solving skills emerged from both field and laboratory research operations when students draw upon and expand their base of practical knowledge via trial and error. Our program has also enjoyed close ties with international partners in Svalbard. Living at the research facility in Ny Alesund under the same roof with biologists, geophysicists and glaciologist highlighted the importance for international and interdisciplinary cooperation necessary in tackling challenging scientific problems in the arctic.
